“温柔地对待她”：以色列军事搜索队如何帮助恢复大部分 Surfside 受害者 以色列国防军国家救援队从 Surfside 的 Champlain Towers South 公寓倒塌现场恢复了 97 名受害者中的 81 人。当以色列国防军国家救援队指挥官 Golan Vach 中校在瑟夫赛德 (Surfside) 倒塌的尚普兰塔南 (Champlain Towers South) 的废墟中搜寻时，发现了一枚男子戒指，他立即知道它属于谁。他知道，因为他见过数十名失踪者的家人。他研究了失踪人员的照片，了解了他们的财产——一条带心形吊坠的项链、一块金表、一张蓝色桌子。他了解了每个潜在受害者的习惯，甚至知道在崩溃期间每个人可能会在哪个房间。而且，在从曾经是他们家的混凝土海洋中伸出的难以想象的钢筋缠结中，他准确地知道每个受害者的位置。他亲自找到了 20 个。他说，当最后一名成员于 7 月 11 日离开 Surfside 时，他的团队找到了 81 个。总的来说，以色列团队找到了近 100 名遇难者中的 84%。
“这就是我们的工作方式，就像侦探一样，”Vach 说。 “你有这些愚蠢、简单、辉煌的迹象。你在这里挖掘，你会找到你要找的人。它奏效了。”在位于以色列北部加利利海以西约 15 英里的 Beit Rimon 家中进行的一系列独家、深入的电话、电子邮件和视频聊天中，Vach 描述了以色列国防军 (IDF) 所发挥的不可或缺的作用从部分倒塌的 13 层高、136 个单元的公寓大楼中救出受害者。碎石到未经训练的眼睛，每一块都是拼图的一部分，导致受害者 未经训练的眼睛看到的是一堆瓦砾，IDF 团队将其视为拼图形式的建筑物。每一块，无论是石柱、混凝土板，还是被压碎的传家宝，都将它们指向可能找到受害者的地方。可悲的是，他们的成功不会导致任何人的获救，而是为悲伤的亲人带来结束和安慰，并为他们提供机会说再见并开始治愈他们破碎的心。 Vach 讲述了如何在获得美国批准加入救援工作的几个小时内，他的团队登上了飞往迈阿密的商业航班。 Vach 说，飞机上有他的代表团的 15 名“最优秀的人”。他们于 6 月 27 日星期日早上 8 点抵达，也就是救援工作的第四天早上。他说，虽然他们计划到中午才开始工作，但团队直接前往坍塌现场。
“这就像一场比赛，大多数跑步者提前几秒钟开始，而你正试图赶上他们，”他说。 “72 小时后，我们不得不非常紧张、非常努力地工作，24/7 全天候在现场，试图找出是否还有活人的迹象。”他说，Vach 做的第一件事就是索取一份失踪人员名单。但他说当局告诉他他们不能发布这些信息。知道家人提供的精确细致的细节对救援工作至关重要，Vach 的团队成员立即开始寻找父母、兄弟姐妹、成年子女、表兄弟和其他亲人的任务，这些亲人因救援工作而苦苦等待。 “我从经验中知道，在这类事件中，每个小时都是昂贵的，”Vach 说。他们发现许多家庭住在以色列国防军所在的同一家酒店。他回忆说，仅仅过了六到八个小时，他的一名团队成员就来找他，她确定了他们应该寻找的人数。但这个数字与美国当局公布的数字不符。 “我说，'但官方数字是 159。你怎么只有 98？'”Vach 说。 “她说，'就是这样。不会超过 98 或 99 人。不会再有一个人了。'”迈阿密-戴德警方报告说，截至周五，已经确定了 97 名受害者，另有一人被归类为“可能失踪”。
Vach 说，Vach 的一半团队会见了受害者家属，另一半则部署到瓦砾堆中。在那里，他们发现急救人员在搜查犬吠叫的区域进行挖掘。 Vach 说，基于丰富的经验，他认为救援人员需要“更广泛的方法来尝试评估人们被埋葬在现场的确切位置。”他说，他的团队没有使用狗，而是使用了一种经过近 40 年磨练的公式。它是从以色列和世界各地（包括黎巴嫩、塞浦路斯、海地、日本、墨西哥、埃及、洪都拉斯和印度）的战争和灾难性事件中的响应任务中获得的专业知识。在 2005 年卡特里娜飓风淹没并摧毁新奥尔良时，该团队甚至随时提供帮助。 因此，就像试图解决最可怕的难题一样，Vach 的团队将其广泛的知识倾注到研究混凝土、钢筋和各种建筑材料以及受害者的消费品和个人财产。该团队还积累了 Vach 所谓的“现场救援情报”，其中包括与其他急救人员合作。他们确定了楼层之间的分界线，确定了柱子与单元相交的地方以及走廊曾经将邻居与邻居联系在一起的地方。在以色列团队的帮助下，Vach 的团队开发了 2-D 和 3-D 计算机模型，以确定建筑物是如何倒塌的，以及哪里可能存在可以支撑生命的“空隙”或裂缝。
结果是一系列数字图像精确显示了每个房间在倒塌前后的位置：红色代表卧室，蓝色代表餐厅，绿色代表厨房，黄色代表走廊。暗红色三角形标记了应该找到受害者的位置。团队在堆中标记了每一列、每个房间、每一层。橙色喷漆和红砖——那是九楼。蓝色喷漆将整个碎片场隔离成一个网格。该团队创造了一个“脆弱的现实”，计算并绘制了一个受害者可能与另一个受害者之间的距离。这样，救援人员可以有目的地搜索，测量距离和方向——向西 13 英尺，向南 33½ 英尺，向东 29 英尺——从每个受害者到可能找到另一个受害者的地方。就这样继续细致地绘​​制网站图表。随着每个人或个人物品的恢复和识别，团队确认或修改了他们的模型。 “他们发现的每个项目都是纠正计划的锚点，”Vach 说。 “如果我假设我在 404 号公寓的 4 楼，但我发现了一张蓝色桌子，并且我知道这张蓝色桌子属于公寓 3，而不是 4 号公寓，那么有什么地方不正确，有什么东西移动了。我必须纠正我的计划。”他说，有一次，另一名救援人员发现了一只死去的狗，正准备丢弃它。 “我说，”不，不要停下来！'”Vach 说。 “看看这座建筑——据我们所知，只有两只狗。一只是斗牛犬，一只是一只大灰狗。每只狗都属于不同的公寓。如果我们确切地知道你在哪里找到这只狗，我们就可以尝试纠正我们的计划。”
瓦赫似乎知道尚普兰塔南的每一个单元号，每一个居民。在提到任何一个时，他都可以识别另一个。 1104 单元，Itty 和 Tzvi Ainsworth。 7 岁的父母，30 岁的祖父母。“当我和 Ainsworth 一家坐在一起时，他们是我唯一详细描述了我如何找到他们、提取他们、将他们拉出来的家庭，”他说。 “这并不容易。” Vach 找到了 Stella Cattarossi，她是迈阿密戴德市一名消防员的 7 岁女儿，她也是搜救队的一员。这个孩子靠近住在 501 单元的她的母亲和祖父母的尸体。 Vach 说，在他的团队的帮助下，在以色列的团队的帮助下找到了另外两名受害者，他发现了一块写着“拉比 AD 戴维斯”的小牌匾。 Vach 回忆说，当时是凌晨 4 点左右，在 20 分钟内，他的团队找到了拉比，当时他不在大楼里，但告诉他们他知道大楼里有一个人。瓦赫说，拉比将牌匾作为礼物送给了住在 1110 单元的布拉德·科恩。“所以我知道我和布拉德很亲近，”瓦赫说他当时想。 7 月 7 日，瓦赫找到了科恩。他还找到了科恩的兄弟加里，他从城外来访。 “你看到了很多死亡，”瓦赫说。 “有些看起来不像人类。我试着把他们当作人，当作灵魂。像对待我的父母一样对待他们。”
尽管如此，找到心爱之人的心碎从未变得如此容易，Vach 轻声说道，他的一些团队真的很挣扎。 “我对他们说，‘嘿，没关系。她等了我们五天才被找到。温柔地对待她。用毯子盖住她。总有一天，你会是一样的，'”他说。以色列总领事 Maor Elbaz Starinsky 表示，严酷的现实是，以色列团队对他们所做的事情如此精通，因为他们有很多机会磨练自己的技能。 “不幸的是，我们在灾难方面有很多经验，”他说。 “以色列城镇和人口中心已成为中东战区的新阵线。 ......因此，我们的军队和当局开发了非常先进的技术，可用于战区以外的地区。”他在以色列家中接受电话采访时说，虽然斯塔林斯基已经在外交部工作了 15 年，但当尚普兰塔南倒塌时，他担任以色列驻迈阿密总领事的新职位仅四天。他说，由于以色列政府的动荡，他在几个月前最初接受该职位后尚未得到确认。
“对于整个任务来说，这是一个非常坎坷的开始，”他说，并补充说以色列外交部长在崩溃后立即指示他“不遗余力”提供协助。 “对我们来说，最自然的事情仍然是，永远都是，向我们最大的盟友提供帮助，”他说。 “以色列永远不会有比美国更好的朋友，美国也永远不会有比以色列更好的盟友或朋友。”斯塔林斯基说，他提供了他的个人信用卡，以帮助那些在崩溃中幸存但失去所有财产的人开处方，并购买毯子、鞋子和食物。他说，他的团队还帮助失踪人员的家人安排了从以色列、委内瑞拉和哥伦比亚等地出发的旅行，当他们抵达迈阿密时，以色列驻华盛顿大使馆为他们提供了进一步帮助。 “这不是犹太人的悲剧，这是人类的悲剧，而是国际的悲剧，”他说。斯塔林斯基说，虽然美军的数量远远超过以色列军队，但以色列军队已经学会了事半功倍。他说：“我们在运营业务的方式上必须非常、非常明智和聪明。” “我们已经学会了成为我们所说的‘小而快’。”
他说，美国和以色列的团队完美地互补，每个团队都利用各自最大的优势尽一切可能从他所谓的“非常戏剧性”、“暴力”的崩溃中营救和恢复受害者。虽然有些人质疑如果以色列国防军团队早点加入，是否可以挽救更多生命，但斯塔林斯基并不确定。 “也许，也许，也许，”他慢慢地说，思考着这个问题。 “我们花了几天时间来证明我们的独特性和效率；为什么值得让我们从半个地球过来帮助美国？”不过，在考虑之后，他说他认为这不会有太大的不同。“可能是因为这件事的性质他说：“我不确定我们是否更早进行了协调，这是否会改变这场灾难的结果。”他说，造成这种情况的主要原因是建筑物倒塌的方式如此不寻常。“当建筑物的一部分被破坏或倒塌时，它不像地震或城市导弹那样，你有很多空隙、洞和隧道他说：“这栋建筑几乎像预期的那样倒塌。当他们内爆另一部分时，它内爆成完美的形状。”
然后，他停顿了片刻，显然被记忆所震撼，然后几乎是在他的呼吸中补充道，“说'完美'这个词真是太糟糕了。”
note_en:
'Treat her gently': How an Israeli military search team helped recover majority of Surfside victims
 The Israeli Defense Forces’ National Rescue Unit recovered 81 of the 97 victims from the Champlain Towers South condo collapse site in Surfside.
     When Lt. Col. Golan Vach, commander of the Israeli Defense Forces’ National Rescue Unit, located a man’s ring while searching the debris field of the collapsed Champlain Towers South in Surfside, he knew immediately to whom it belonged.
 He knew, because he had met with families of the scores of missing people. He had studied photographs of the missing, learned about  their possessions — a necklace with a heart pendant, a gold watch, a blue table.
 He had learned about the habits of each potential victim and even knew in which room each likely would have been during the collapse.
 And, amid unimaginable tangles of rebar jutting out from a sea of concrete that was once their homes, he knew precisely where each victim would be located.
  He personally found 20. His team, he said, recovered 81 by the time the last member departed Surfside on July 11. In all, the Israeli team found about 84% of the nearly 100 victims.
 “This is the way we were working, like detectives,” Vach said. “You have these stupid, simple, brilliant signs. You dig here, and you will find the people you are looking for. And it worked.”
     In a series of exclusive, in-depth phone calls, emails and video chats from his home in Beit Rimon — located about 15 miles west of the Sea of Galilee in northern Israel — Vach described the integral role the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) played in recovering victims from the partially collapsed, 13-story, 136-unit condominium complex.
  Rubble to untrained eye, each piece was part of a puzzle that led to victims
 What the untrained eye saw as a pile of rubble the IDF team viewed as a building in puzzle form. And each piece, whether a stone column, slab of concrete, or crushed family heirloom, pointed them toward where a victim might be found.
 Sadly, their success would not result in anyone's rescue, but rather in bringing closure and solace to grieving loved ones and providing them an opportunity to say goodbye and begin to heal their broken hearts.
  Vach related how,  within hours of receiving approval from the U.S. to join the rescue efforts, his team boarded a commercial flight to Miami.
 On the plane were 15 of his delegation's “best people,” Vach said. They arrived at 8 a.m. on Sunday, June 27, the morning of the fourth day of rescue efforts. And while they were not scheduled to begin work until noon, he said, the team headed straight to the collapse site.
  “It’s like a race where most of the runners began a few seconds ahead and you are trying to catch them,” he said. “After 72 hours, we had to work very tight, very hard, to be onsite 24/7 to try to find out if there are still signs of a living person.”
 The first thing Vach did, he said, was request a list of missing persons. But he said authorities told him they could not release that information.
   Knowing precise and meticulous details provided by family members would be crucial to rescue efforts, members of Vach’s team immediately began the task of searching out parents, siblings, adult children, cousins and other loved ones stuck in agonizing wait for word on rescue efforts.
 "I know from experience that each hour is expensive in those kinds of incidents," Vach said.
 They found many families staying in the same hotel where the IDF team was housed. In only six to eight hours, he recalled, one of his team members came to him with what she determined would be the number of people for whom they should be searching. But that number didn’t match the one put out by U.S. authorities.
  “I said, ‘But the official numbers are 159. How come you have only 98?’” Vach said. “And she said, ‘This is it. There will be no more than 98 or 99. Not a single one more.’”
 As of Friday, 97 victims had been identified, reported Miami-Dade Police, with one more categorized as “potentially missing.”
    While half of Vach’s team met with victims’ families, the other half deployed to the rubble pile, Vach said. There, they found first responders digging in areas where search dogs were barking.
 Based on vast experience, Vach said, he believed the rescuers would need a “much wider methodology to try to evaluate where exactly people were buried in the site.”
  His team did not use dogs, he said, but rather a formula that had been honed over almost 40 years. It was expertise developed from responder missions in wars and catastrophic events in Israel and around the world, including in Lebanon, Cyprus, Haiti, Japan, Mexico, Egypt, Honduras and India. The team had even been on hand to assist during Hurricane Katrina when it flooded and devastated New Orleans in 2005.
  So, like attempting to solve the most gruesome of puzzles, Vach’s team poured its sweeping knowledge into studying the pile of concrete, rebar and assorted building materials along with victims' consumer goods and personal possessions.
 The team also amassed what Vach called "field rescue intelligence," which included collaborating with other first responders.
 They identified dividing lines between floors, determined where columns intersected units and where hallways once linked neighbor to neighbor.
  With help from his team back in Israel, Vach's group developed 2-D and 3-D computer models to determine how the building had fallen and where there might be “voids'' or crevices that could support life.
 The result was a series of digital images that showed precisely where each room was located both before and after the collapse: red for bedrooms, blue for dining rooms, green for kitchens, yellow for corridors. A dark red triangle marked the spot where a victim should be found.
  The team marked each column, each room, each floor in the pile. Orange spray paint and red brick — that was the ninth floor. Blue spray paint segregated the entire debris field into a grid.
 The team created a “fragile reality,” calculating and mapping how far one victim might have landed from another. That way, rescuers could search with purpose, measuring out the distance and direction — 13 feet to the west, 33½ feet to the south, 29 feet to the east — from each victim to where another might be found.
  And so continued the meticulous process of diagramming the site. With each person or personal item recovered and identified, the team confirmed or modified their model.
 “Each item that they found is an anchor to correct the plan,” Vach said. “If I assume I am on Floor 4 in apartment 404, but I found a blue table, and I know the blue table belonged to Apartment 3, not 4, then something is incorrect, something moved. And I have to correct my plan.”
  Once, he said, another rescuer found a deceased dog and was about to discard it.
 “I said, “No, no stop!'” Vach said. “Look at this building — according to what we know there were only two dogs. One was a pit bull and one was a big gray dog. Each dog belonged to a different apartment. If we know exactly where you found this dog, we can try to correct our plan.”
  Vach seemed to know every unit number, every resident of Champlain Towers South. At the mention of either, he can identify the other. Unit 1104,  Itty and Tzvi Ainsworth. Parents to seven, grandparents to 30.
 “When I sat with the Ainsworth family, they were the only family that I described in detail how I found them, extracted them, pulled them out,” he said. “It’s not easy.”
  Vach recovered Stella Cattarossi, the 7-year-old daughter of a Miami-Dade firefighter who was also part of the search-and-rescue team. The child was near the body of her mother and grandparents, who lived in unit 501.
  Two other victims were located with the help of his team back in Israel, Vach said, after he found a tiny plaque that read “Rabbi A. D. Davis.” It was around 4 a.m., Vach recalled, and within 20 minutes, his team had located the rabbi, who was not in the building at the time but told them he knew of a person in the building.
  Vach said the rabbi had given the plaque as a gift to Brad Cohen, who lived in unit 1110. "So I know I am close to Brad," Vach said he thought at the time.
 On July 7, Vach found Cohen. He also found Cohen’s brother, Gary, who was visiting from out of town.
 “You see a lot of death,” Vach said. “Some do not look like human beings. I tried to treat them as people, as souls. Treat them as if they were my parents.”
 Still, the heartbreak of finding someone’s loved one never gets easier, Vach said softly, and some of his team really struggled.
 “I say to them, ‘Hey, it's OK. She was waiting for us for five days to be found. Treat her gently. Cover her with a blanket. One day, you will be the same,’” he said.
   The harsh reality, said Maor Elbaz Starinsky, the consul general of Israel, is that the Israeli teams are so proficient at what they do because they have had so much opportunity to sharpen their skills.
 “Unfortunately, we have a lot of experience with disasters,” he said. “Israeli towns and cities and population centers have become the new front for the war zone in the Middle East. ...
 So our military and authorities have developed very advanced techniques that are useful in territories other than war zones.”
  While Starinsky already had 15 years' experience in the foreign ministry, he was only four days into his new position as Israeli consul general in Miami when Champlain Towers South collapsed, he said in a telephone interview from his home in Israel.
 He said he had not been confirmed after initially accepting the position months earlier because of turmoil in the Israeli government.
  “It was a really bumpy start for this whole mission,” he said, adding that the Israeli foreign minister immediately after the collapse instructed him to “spare no effort” in assisting.
 “For us, the most natural thing still is, and forever will be, to offer our help to our biggest ally,” he said. “Israel will never have a better friend than the U.S., and the U.S. will never have a better ally or friend than Israel.”
   Starinsky said he provided his personal credit card to help fill prescriptions and buy blankets, shoes and food for those who had survived the collapse but lost all of their possessions.
 His team also helped family members of the missing arrange travel from places such as Israel, Venezuela and Colombia, he said, and the Israeli Embassy in Washington helped them even further when they arrived in Miami.
  "This is not a Jewish tragedy, this is a human tragedy, it’s an international tragedy," he said.
 Starinsky said that while U.S. forces vastly outnumber Israeli forces, Israeli forces have learned to do more with less.
 "We have to be very, very wise and clever in the way we run our operations," he said. "We have learned to be what we call 'small and swift.'"
  U.S. and Israeli teams complemented one another beautifully, he said, each drawing on their greatest strengths to do everything possible to rescue and recover victims from what he called a “very dramatic,” “violent” collapse.
  And while some have questioned if more lives could have been saved if the IDF team had been brought in sooner, Starinsky is not so sure.
 “Maybe, maybe, maybe,” he said slowly, contemplating the question. “It took us a few days to prove our uniqueness, our efficiency; why it was worth schlepping us, commuting us, from halfway across the world to help the U.S."
  Still, after thinking about it, he said he doesn't think it would have made much difference.
 “Probably, because of the nature of this collapse, everybody died instantly or very close to instantly,” he said. “I'm not sure if we had the coordination earlier it would change the result of this disaster.”
 The primary reason for that, he said, was the way the building collapsed was so unusual.
 “It was not like an earthquake or urban missiles when part of the building is broken or falls down and you have a lot of voids and holes and tunnels that are created,” he said. “This building collapsed almost as if it was intended. When they  imploded the other part, it imploded in the perfect shape.”
 Then, he paused for a moment, clearly shaken by the memory, before adding almost under his breath, “It's a terrible word to say, ‘perfect.’”
title: 以色列国防军恢复了 80% 的迈阿密坍塌遗迹

note:
根据以色列卫生部的一份新报告，辉瑞和 BioNTech 的 Covid-19 疫苗在以色列的有效性仅为 39%，其中 delta 变体是主要毒株，但仍能提供强有力的保护，防止严重疾病和住院治疗。疗效数据基于 6 月 20 日至 7 月 17 日期间未指明人数的数据，低于两周前早期估计的 64%，并且与来自英国的数据相冲突，该数据表明该疫苗对有症状的患者有 88% 的有效性。变异引起的疾病。然而，根据以色列周四公布的数据，两剂疫苗在预防人们患重病方面仍然非常有效，对住院的有效率为 88%，对严重疾病的有效率为 91%。 “我们必须注意，随着时间的推移，这些疫苗的有效性可能会减弱，”多伦多大学传染病教授 Isaac Bogoch 博士说。他强调，这些疫苗在预防严重感染方面仍然非常有效，有助于医院系统在进入寒冷月份时不会过于不堪重负。话虽如此，“我们仍处于 Covid 时代，任何事情都有可能发生，”他说。 “我们必须做好准备，我们必须灵活应对人们可能在某个时候需要助推器，”他补充道。 “在以色列、英国和世界其他地区等国家进行的这种密切监视将非常有助于推动政策，如果我们确实需要助推器的话。” delta 变异已经在超过 104 个国家/地区出现，引起美国卫生官员的关注，因为他们看到更多的突破性感染发生在完全接种疫苗的人群中，尽管他们的症状更轻。
白宫首席医疗官安东尼·福奇博士说，完全接种疫苗的人可能会考虑在室内戴口罩，以预防这种病毒在美国迅速传播 健康专家担心秋季，预计 delta 将袭击疫情最严重的州疫苗接种率最高——除非这些州和企业重新引入口罩规定、容量限制和其他他们已经基本取消的公共卫生措施。 “这显然是我们不想看到的，”福奇周三说，并指出了所谓的突破性感染。 “这种病毒显然不同于我们之前接触过的病毒和变种。它具有非凡的人际传播能力。”为 FDA 提供 Covid 疫苗建议的 Paul Offit 博士说，虽然这些疫苗仍能提供极好的预防严重疾病和死亡的保护，但它们对轻度病例或将疾病传播给他人可能效果不佳。他敦促更多美国人接种疫苗，称 delta 是一种具有高度传染性的病毒，疫苗将帮助人们避免重病。根据疾病预防控制中心汇编的数据，目前只有不到一半的美国人口完全接种了疫苗。 “这是病毒继续自我繁殖并继续创造可能对疫苗或自然感染越来越有抵抗力的变种的肥沃土壤，”他说。世卫组织官员周一表示，世界各地的人们未接种疫苗和社会融合持续的时间越长，出现更危险变异的风险就越高。
以色列的报告先于许多其他国家开始为其人口接种疫苗，这可能会支持制药商的论点，即人们最终需要接种加强疫苗以预防新出现的变异。辉瑞本月早些时候表示，它开始看到其两剂疫苗的免疫力下降，现在计划寻求食品和药物管理局的授权以获得加强剂量。然而，联邦官员表示，完全接种疫苗的美国人此时不需要额外注射。辉瑞在给 CNBC 的一份声明中表示，它仍然相信其两剂方案可以预防冠状病毒及其变种。尽管如此，它表示，在其第三阶段研究的分析显示，在四到六个月后，对有症状感染的疗效下降后，第三剂可能会有所帮助。 “当前疫苗第三剂的初始数据表明，在第二剂接种后至少 6 个月给予加强剂量会引起对野生型和 Beta 的高中和效价，比两次主要剂量后高 5 到 10 倍， “该公司表示。
note_en:
Pfizer and  BioNTech's Covid-19 vaccine is just 39% effective in Israel where the delta variant is the dominant strain, but still provides strong protection against severe illness and hospitalization, according to a new report from the country's Health Ministry.
 The efficacy figure, which is based on an unspecified number of people between June 20 and July 17, is down from an earlier estimate of  64% two weeks ago and conflicts with data out of the U.K. that found the shot was 88% effective against symptomatic disease caused by the variant.
  However, the two-dose vaccine still works very well in preventing people from getting seriously sick, demonstrating 88% effectiveness against hospitalization and 91% effectiveness against severe illness, according to the Israeli data published Thursday.
 "We have to be mindful that, with time, the effectiveness of these vaccines may wane," said Dr. Isaac Bogoch, an infectious disease professor at the University of Toronto.
  He stressed that the shots are still highly effective in preventing severe infection, helping hospital systems not get too overwhelmed heading into the colder months. That being said, "we're still in the Covid era and anything can happen," he said.
 "We have to be prepared and we have to be nimble that people may need a booster at some point," he added. "This close surveillance that's happening in countries like Israel, the U.K. and other parts of the world is going to be very helpful in driving policy if and when we do need boosters."
 The delta variant, already in more than 104 countries, is concerning health officials in the U.S. as they see more breakthrough infections, which occur in fully vaccinated people, even though they are more mild.
  White House chief medical officer Dr. Anthony Fauci said fully vaccinated people might want to consider wearing masks indoors as a precaution against the rapidly spreading variant in the U.S.
 Health experts are  concerned about the fall season, when delta is expected to hit states with the lowest vaccination rates the hardest — unless those states and businesses reintroduce mask rules, capacity limits and other public health measures that they've largely rolled back.
 "That's something we obviously don't want to see," Fauci  said Wednesday, noting the so-called breakthrough infections. "This virus is clearly different than the viruses and the variants that we've had experience with before. It has an extraordinary capability of transmitting from person to person."
 Dr. Paul Offit, who advises the FDA on Covid vaccines, said while the vaccines still provide excellent protection against severe disease and death, they may not work as well against mild cases or spreading the disease to others.
 He urged more Americans to get vaccinated, saying delta is a highly contagious virus and the shots will help people from getting seriously sick. Currently, less than half of the U.S. population is fully vaccinated, according to data compiled by the CDC.
 "That is a rich and fertile ground for the virus to continue to reproduce itself and continue to create variants that possibly become more and more resistant to vaccines or natural infection," he said.
 WHO officials said Monday that the longer that people around the world remain unvaccinated and social mixing continues, the higher the risk of a more dangerous variant to emerge.
 The report out of Israel, which began vaccinating its population ahead of many other countries, is likely to bolster arguments from drugmakers that people will eventually need to get booster shots to protect against emerging variants.
 Pfizer  said earlier this month it is starting to see waning immunity from its two-dose vaccine, and now plans to seek authorization from the Food and Drug Administration for a booster dose. However, federal officials say fully vaccinated Americans do not need additional shots at this time.
 In a statement to CNBC, Pfizer said it remains confident its two-dose regimen is protective against the coronavirus and its variants.
 Still, it said a third dose may be helpful after analysis from its phase three study showed a decline in efficacy against symptomatic infection after four to six months.
 "Initial data of a third dose of the current vaccine demonstrates that a booster dose given at least 6 months after the second dose elicits high neutralization titers against the wild type and the Beta, which are 5 to 10 times higher than after two primary doses," the company said.
title: 以色列表示，随着 delta 的蔓延，辉瑞 Covid 疫苗的有效性仅为 39%
title_en: Israel says Pfizer Covid vaccine is just 39% effective as delta spreads

note: 我的个人 Facebook 帐户已被错误停用，因为我试图在 FB 市场以及其他专注于棋盘游戏的 FB 群组中出售我使用过的棋盘游戏“秘密希特勒”的副本。我猜 FB 的算法根据棋盘游戏的名称标记了这一点，并禁用了我违反社区标准的帐户，尽管人们可以很容易地看出它没有上下文。这显然是一个错误，但在我对该决定提出上诉后，FB 并没有改变他们的决定，我也没有其他选择可以上诉。我完全不知道如何纠正这个问题，尤其令人沮丧，因为我的个人 FB 帐户不仅与我的 Oculus 库（我无法再访问）而且我的 FB 业务页面相关联。完全荒谬。
note_en: My personal facebook account has been deactivated mistakenly because I attempted to sell my used copy of the board game "Secret Hitler" in FB marketplace, among other boardgame focused FB groups. I am guessing FB's algorithms flagged this due to the name of the boardgame and disabled my account for violating the community standards although one can easily see that it is without context. This is obviously a mistake and yet after I appealed the decision, FB has not changed their decision and I have no other options to appeal. I am completely bewildered as to how to rectify this and it is particularly frustrating as my personal FB account is tied to not only my Oculus library (which I can no longer access) but also my FB business page. Completely absurd.

特斯拉首席执行官埃隆·马斯克之前曾就电池供应限制及其可能对特斯拉 Semi 产生的影响发出警告，特斯拉 Semi 于 2017 年 11 月首次作为原型亮相。早在 1 月份，马斯克就表示，特斯拉 Semi 的工程工作已经完成并预计今年开始交付。他当时确实补充说，电池的可用性可能会限制公司生产 Semi 的能力。这个警告显然是有道理的。摘自今天收盘后发布的股东信：我们相信我们仍有望在 2021 年在柏林和奥斯汀制造我们的第一辆 Model Y 汽车。各自的生产速度将受到许多新产品的成功推出的影响和制造技术、持续的供应链相关挑战和区域许可。为了更好地专注于这些工厂，由于电池供应有限和全球供应链挑战，我们将半卡车计划的启动时间推迟到 2022 年。我们也在推进 Cyber​​truck 的产业化，目前计划Model Y 之后的奥斯汀生产。 虽然在电话会议或收益报告中没有提到，但延迟是在特斯拉的关键高管杰罗姆·吉伦 (Jerome Guillen) 离职之后进行的，他正致力于特斯拉 Semi 的开发和最终生产。 Guillen 于 6 月辞职，仅仅三个月后，他就从汽车总裁职位（包括监督特斯拉 Semi 公司）调任重型卡车运输主管的职责较少的职位。从 2018 年 9 月到 2021 年 3 月，Guillen 一直领导着特斯拉的整个汽车业务。 与此同时，原定于 2021 年底投产的特斯拉 Cyber​​truck 看起来也可能会被推迟到明年。马斯克没有回答问题，但马斯克和特斯拉工程副总裁 Lars Moravy 在财报电话会议上的评论表明，它可能会转移到 2022 年。 Cyber​​truck 目前处于原型设计的 alpha 阶段，具有基本的工程和架构车辆完成。 Moravy 说，虽然 Model Y 优先，但该公司将在今年晚些时候进入 Cyber​​truck 的测试阶段。
“在 Model Y 启动并运行后，我们将寻求在德克萨斯州提高产量，”他补充道。马斯克认为 Cyber​​truck 的难度有多大，或许是为了缓和对 2021 年到来的预期。“Cyber​​truck 坡道将很困难，因为它是一种新架构，”马斯克说。 “这将是一个很棒的产品；它可能是我们有史以来最好的产品，但它确实有很多全新的设计理念。”他继续指出，当其他车辆从原型车转向批量生产时，他曾使用过的观点是：制造很难。 “冒着重复的风险，制作原型或少量小批量生产实际上很容易，但是任何大批量生产的东西，这真的很重要，它是否会像最慢的一样快大约 10,000 个独特零件和工艺的数量级。”
note_en:
Tesla CEO Elon Musk has warned about battery supply constraints before and the effect it might have on the Tesla Semi, which was first unveiled as a prototype in November 2017. Back in January, Musk said the engineering work on the Tesla Semi had been completed and  deliveries were expected to begin this year. He did add the caveat, at the time, that the availability of battery cells could limit the company’s ability to produce the Semi.
 That warning was apparently warranted. From the shareholders’ letter posted today after the market closed:
  We believe we remain on track to build our first Model Y vehicles in Berlin and Austin in 2021. The pace of the respective production ramps will be influenced by the successful introduction of many new product and manufacturing technologies, ongoing supply-chain-related challenges and regional permitting.
 To better focus on these factories, and due to the limited availability of battery cells and global supply chain challenges, we have shifted the launch of the Semi truck program to 2022. We are also making progress on the industrialization of Cybertruck, which is currently planned for Austin production subsequent to Model Y.
 While not mentioned on the call or in its earnings report, the delay follows the departure of Jerome Guillen, a critical executive at Tesla who was working on the development and eventual production of the Tesla Semi. Guillen’s resignation in June came just three months after he was moved from the president of automotive position, which included oversight of the Tesla Semi, to a role with less responsibility as head of heavy-duty trucking. Guillen had led Tesla’s entire automotive business from September 2018 until March 2021.
 Meanwhile, Tesla’s Cybertruck, which is supposed to go into production in late 2021, looks like it might be pushed into next year as well. Musk didn’t answer questions, but comments from Musk as well as Tesla VP of engineering Lars Moravy during the earnings call suggest that it could shift to 2022.
 Cybertruck is currently in its alpha stages of prototyping, with the basic engineering and architecture of the vehicle completed. While the Model Y takes priority, the company is moving into a beta phase of the Cybertruck later this year, Moravy said.
 “We’ll be looking to ramp that in production in Texas after Model Y is up and going,” he added.
 Musk leaned in on how difficult the Cybertruck would be, perhaps as a way to cushion expectations for its arrival in 2021.
 “Cybertruck ramp will be difficult because it is such a new architecture,” Musk said. “It’s going to be a great product; it might be our best product ever, but it does have a lot of fundamentally new design ideas.”
 He went on to make the point that he has used as other vehicles have gone from prototype to volume production: Manufacturing is hard.
 “At the risk of being repetitive, it’s actually easy to make prototypes or a handful of small-volume production, but anything produced at a high volume, which is really what’s relevant here, is it’s going to move as fast as the slowest of the rough order of magnitude of 10,000 unique parts and processes.”
title: 特斯拉将半挂卡车推迟到 2022 年； Cyber​​truck 为 Model Y 提供支持
title_en: Tesla delays Semi truck to 2022; Cybertruck back-burnered for Model Y
